subject: Quory CSS
body: Sometimes people ask me if I ever run out of ideas for content, considering I basically only talk about CSS. With my channel going on 7 years now(!) and with almost 600 videos(!!!), it could definitely be a real possibility‚Ä¶ if it weren‚Äôt for the fact that CSS seems to be exploding of late.With Chrome 111 (currently in Beta), they‚Äôve just added a ton of features, all of which I could make quite a bit of content around!Just for CSS, we‚Äôre gettingAdvanced :nth-child selectorsTrigonometric functions

color-mix() and HD color spaceStyle querieView transitions API supporNot only is that a lot of things, but they‚Äôre all pretty exciting things at that!,I‚Äôm most excited for style queries, which are a part of the container queries spec, but all of them open up new doors that ranged from ‚ÄúI need a pre-processor for this‚Äù to ‚Äúthat was impossible without this new feature‚Äù.Of course, one browser supporting a bunch of awesome features isn‚Äôt enough to start using them, but many of these were already supported by Safari.But with two browsers supporting something, I do feel comfortable to start making content around those things, so in a way that list is a bit of a preview for things to come in the coming months And of course, even if Firefox was up to date on these as well, it would raise the question of when we can actually use them in production.I think many even now could be used as progressive enhancements.

I‚Äôve used grids masonry layout on my own site for a few years already, as an example.Everything works fine if you are on a browser that doesn‚Äôt support it, but it looks better if you‚Äôre on one that does

hrome without masonry on left, Firefox with masonry on the rightEventually, we‚Äôll be able to start using features like this more and more, but always do keep an eye on your own site‚Äôs analytics to have a general idea of your audience. That‚Äôs the best way to know when you can start using some of these fancy new things!üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è What I‚Äôve been up to this week3D tilting card effect with mouse tracking A few weeks ago, I had a thumbnail that had a 3D-looking code block in it, and I sort of felt like making it with CSS.With it being 3D, it sort of left like it would be worth making it follow the mouse around, so I did that too

There are JS libraries out there, like tiltJS, but it‚Äôs actually pretty simple to pull off without it When I shared that I was working on that on my YT community feed, people asked if it was possible to track the mouse with CSS-only.The above GIF is using JavaScript, but since several people asked about a CSS-only solution, I figured it was worth exploring.So, I took a look at all of that in this video.The CSS-only solution is a little hacky, but it‚Äôs always fun to see how we can do something like that, even if it‚Äôs not the most practical thing in the world.The problem with Viewport Unit

Circling back to browser support, you might have heard that Interlop 2023 was recently put out.Interlop is a cross-browser effort to basically make sure everything is working in all browsers, and that it all works the same across the different rendering engines.This does mean progressing on features like the ones mentioned above, but it also means fixing cross-browser irregularities with existing features, including things like flexbox, where all the browsers still have a least a few little things they don‚Äôt handle correctly.They do this by putting together automated tests to run in

subject: Learn to code your own physics-based action game [free 3-hour GameDev course]x
body: Here are this week's five links that are worth your time:/n1. It's 2023 and not only can you play other people's video games ‚Äì

you can build games yourself. This freeCodeCamp GameDev course will teach you how to use JavaScript to code your own physics-based action game. You'll learn how to animate game sprites, implement collision detection, and program enemy AI. Along the way, you'll learn some CSS3, vanilla JavaScript, HTML Canvas, and other broadly useful open source tools. (3 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/create-an-animated-physics-game-with-javascript/

2. What's the simplest way to get started with Python web development? Well, many developers will recommend Flask. You can learn the basics of this light-weight web development framework in just a few hours of study. This Python Web Development course will teach you how to build and deploy a production-ready, database-driven Flask app. (4 hour YouTube course): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/develop-database-driven-web-apps-with-python-flask-and-mysql/

3. z-index is easily one of the most confusing properties in all of CSS. It controls how HTML elements appear on the page, and how close they are to your user's eyeballs. This beginner tutorial will teach you about  It will give you a solid mental model. Soon you too will understand how your browser's DOM renders elements on top of one another. (40 minute read): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/z-index-property-and-stacking-order-css/

4. What are URIs? What are HTTP Headers? How does DNS work? This HTTP Networking Handbook will teach you many of the fundamentals about how the web works, with lots of helpful illustrations. You can bookmark it to use it as a reference. And freeCodeCamp also published a 4-hour video course to accompany it if you want to go even deeper. (full-length book): https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/http-full-course/

subject: Your feedback matters to us
body: Sometimes people ask me if I ever run out of ideas for content, considering I basically only talk about CSS. With my channel going on 7 years now(!) and with almost 600 videos(!!!), it could definitely be a real possibility‚Ä¶ if it weren‚Äôt for the fact that CSS seems to be exploding of late.With Chrome 111 (currently in Beta), they‚Äôve just added a ton of features, all of which I could make quite a bit of content around!Just for CSS, we‚Äôre gettingAdvanced :nth-child selectorsTrigonometric functions

color-mix() and HD color spaceStyle querieView transitions API supporNot only is that a lot of things, but they‚Äôre all pretty exciting things at that!,I‚Äôm most excited for style queries, which are a part of the container queries spec, but all of them open up new doors that ranged from ‚ÄúI need a pre-processor for this‚Äù to ‚Äúthat was impossible without this new feature‚Äù.Of course, one browser supporting a bunch of awesome features isn‚Äôt enough to start using them, but many of these were already supported by Safari.But with two browsers supporting something, I do feel comfortable to start making content around those things, so in a way that list is a bit of a preview for things to come in the coming months And of course, even if Firefox was up to date on these as well, it would raise the question of when we can actually use them in production.I think many even now could be used as progressive enhancements.

I‚Äôve used grids masonry layout on my own site for a few years already, as an example.Everything works fine if you are on a browser that doesn‚Äôt support it, but it looks better if you‚Äôre on one that does

hrome without masonry on left, Firefox with masonry on the rightEventually, we‚Äôll be able to start using features like this more and more, but always do keep an eye on your own site‚Äôs analytics to have a general idea of your audience. That‚Äôs the best way to know when you can start using some of these fancy new things!üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è What I‚Äôve been up to this week3D tilting card effect with mouse tracking A few weeks ago, I had a thumbnail that had a 3D-looking code block in it, and I sort of felt like making it with CSS.With it being 3D, it sort of left like it would be worth making it follow the mouse around, so I did that too

There are JS libraries out there, like tiltJS, but it‚Äôs actually pretty simple to pull off without it When I shared that I was working on that on my YT community feed, people asked if it was possible to track the mouse with CSS-only.The above GIF is using JavaScript, but since several people asked about a CSS-only solution, I figured it was worth exploring.So, I took a look at all of that in this video.The CSS-only solution is a little hacky, but it‚Äôs always fun to see how we can do something like that, even if it‚Äôs not the most practical thing in the world.The problem with Viewport Unit

Circling back to browser support, you might have heard that Interlop 2023 was recently put out.Interlop is a cross-browser effort to basically make sure everything is working in all browsers, and that it all works the same across the different rendering engines.This does mean progressing on features like the ones mentioned above, but it also means fixing cross-browser irregularities with existing features, including things like flexbox, where all the browsers still have a least a few little things they don‚Äôt handle correctly.They do this by putting together automated tests to run in

I‚Äôve used grids masonry layout on my own site for a few years already, as an example.Everything works fine if you are on a browser that doesn‚Äôt support it, but it looks better if you‚Äôre on one that does

hrome without masonry on left, Firefox with masonry on the rightEventually, we‚Äôll be able to start using features like this more and more, but always do keep an eye on your own site‚Äôs analytics to have a general idea of your audience. That‚Äôs the best way to know when you can start using some of these fancy new things!üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è What I‚Äôve been up to this week3D tilting card effect with mouse tracking A few weeks ago, I had a thumbnail that had a 3D-looking code block in it, and I sort of felt like making it with CSS.With it being 3D, it sort of left like it would be worth making it follow the mouse around, so I did that too

There are JS libraries out there, like tiltJS, but it‚Äôs actually pretty simple to pull off without it When I shared that I was working on that on my YT community feed, people asked if it was possible to track the mouse with CSS-only.The above GIF is using JavaScript, but since several people asked about a CSS-only solution, I figured it was worth exploring.So, I took a look at all of that in this video.The CSS-only solution is a little hacky, but it‚Äôs always fun to see how we can do something like that, even if it‚Äôs not the most practical thing in the world.The problem with Viewport Unit
